title: St. Michael's Preparatory School (Silverado, California)
text:
Saint Michael's Preparatory School was a <a href="private%20school">private</a>, <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a>, college preparatory boys' boarding school in <a href="Silverado%2C%20California">Silverado, California</a>. It was located in the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Orange">Roman Catholic Diocese of Orange</a>. 
It was owned and operated by the <a href="Norbertine%20Fathers">Norbertine Fathers</a> of <a href="St.%20Michael%27s%20Abbey%20%28Orange%20County%2C%20California%29">St. Michael's Abbey</a>, who established it in 1961 as St. Michael's Junior Seminary and Novitiate. The school was closed in June 2020.
Faith.
St. Michael's was run by the <a href="Norbertine%20Fathers">Norbertine Order</a>. An abbey school, it adjoins a <a href="St.%20Michael%27s%20Abbey%20%28Orange%20County%2C%20California%29">community of 60 priests</a>, many of whom teach at the school.
<a href="Religious%20Education">Religious education</a> was compulsory for all students, as was daily attendance at morning <a href="Mass%20%28liturgy%29">mass</a> before breakfast and <a href="compline">night prayer</a> after supper. Studies in <a href="Latin">Latin</a> were also mandatory, except for the students who take Spanish.
Academics.
St. Michael's Prep offered a classical sequence of courses at College Prep, Honors, and Advanced Placement levels. It was the only boarding school to rank among the top fifty Catholic high schools in the nation. 
Mr. Lieggi carried the science educational department at the school. 100% of its graduates go on to institutions of higher learning. It was considered a highly selective high school.
Character.
St. Michael's educated young men in fidelity to the Catholic intellectual tradition. It was exclusively a boarding school, with students and teachers living and working together in five-day & seven-day boarding programs. St. Michael's offers significant opportunities for wholesome growth through clear standards.
Good behavior was enforced among the students through the "conduct grade" which directly impacted student <a href="GPA">GPA</a>, and a system of <a href="Prefect%23Academic">prefects</a> called "roomleaders".
Most students participated in one or more <a href="Student%20athlete">sports</a>. These include <a href="Cross%20country%20running">cross country</a> and <a href="American%20football">football</a> in the fall, <a href="soccer">soccer</a> in the winter, and <a href="baseball">baseball</a> in the spring. <a href="Underclassmen%23First%20year">Underclassmen</a> who do not participated in a sport must take the <a href="physical%20education">physical education</a> class. The school mascot was the "Pioneer".
Each year during <a href="Christmas">Christmas</a> vacation, the <a href="Eleventh%20grade">Junior class</a> traveled to <a href="Rome">Rome</a> for two weeks under the supervision of several <a href="teacher">teacher</a>s and parent chaperones.
History.
St. Michael's Abbey was founded in 1961 by seven priests from the <a href="Norbertine">Norbertine</a> Abbey of St. Michael in <a href="Csorna">Csorna</a>, <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>, whose roots go back to the 12th century. 
The <a href="Norbertine">Norbertine</a> priests in the 1940s were well-established teachers in the national educational system of <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a> that encompassed religious and secular schools alike. All private schools, however, were nationalized by 1948. Two groups of priests from the <a href="Norbertine">Norbertine</a> Abbey of <a href="Csorna">Csorna</a> fled their native land on separated July nights in 1950. Shortly thereafter, their religious community was suppressed. On the night of July 11, 1950, word came to the Abbey in Csorna that the police would arrive the next day to arrest the conferred and suppress the community. Seven priests left that night in two groups to hike across country to the Austrian border.
The <a href="Hungarian%20people">Hungarian</a> refugeed emigrated to <a href="United%20States">America</a>. Arriving in New York in 1952, they were welcomed by the Abbey of St. Norbert in <a href="De%20Pere%2C%20Wisconsin">De Pere, Wisconsin</a>, with whom they worked for several years, saving money to begin their own monastery. At the invitation of Cardinal McIntyre, archbishop of Los Angeles, they first moved to <a href="Santa%20Ana%2C%20California">Santa Ana, California</a> in 1957 and taught at <a href="Mater%20Dei%20High%20School%20%28Santa%20Ana%2C%20California%29">Mater Dei High School</a>, establishing a monastic community the next year. The founding abbot was the Rt. Rev. Ladislaus Parker, O.Praem. The exiled saw the move to <a href="Orange%20County%2C%20California">Orange County, California</a> as their chance to establish a new foundation.
In December 1958 <a href="James%20Francis%20McIntyre">Cardinal McIntyre</a> gave his consent to the Fathers establishing their own foundation. Their desire was fueled by the desire to perpetuated the religious and educational heritage of their native <a href="Csorna">Csorna</a>. Under the leadership of Fr. Ladislas Parker, the Fathers invested their savings to purchase property. 
Fr. Hubert Szanto joined Fr. Parker to open St. Michael's Junior Seminary and Novitiated in September 1961. St. Michael's opened this Junior Seminary in 1962, which would evolve into the present day Preparatory School.
Rapid changed in American society and in the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a> prompted Fr. Parker to petition Cardinal McIntyre to allow the school to introduce a parallel college preparatory program for lay students. This petition uniquely changed St. Michael's.
When the 1970s began, St. Michael's was flourishing more as a high school than as a seminary. As the number of those interested in the priesthood at the high school level continued to dwindle, the parallel programs gradually merged into one.
Back in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, educational programs similar to St. Michael's were closing. Thus, by 1995, St. Michael's Prep became the only institution where Catholic, secondary education was available in the entire Western United Stated for those seeking to study in an all-male, residential environment.
